question: Question_03_(b)_i
statement:
\textbf{Continuous Probability}.

\textbf{Consider $\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x}}$. Convert
$\displaystyle f(x)$ into a probability density function (pdf)
$\displaystyle p(x)$ on an interval $\displaystyle (a,b)$}

With $\displaystyle p(x) = cf(x)$, find the minimal \emph{a}, maximal
\emph{b}, and the constant $\displaystyle c > 0$
sols:
Firstly, notice that in order for the denominator to be well defined, we
require that $\displaystyle 1-x > 0$ (strictly greater than 0 since the
denominator of a fraction cannot be 0). This gives us that \emph{b} has
value 1 if it is to be maximal. Now, for a to be minimal, we notice that
the denominator is always positive if \emph{a} is less than 1 so that
gives no restriction. However the numerator has to be positive in order
to have a pdf and so we require that \emph{a} is greater than 0. Lastly,
the area condition on a pdf shows us that

$\displaystyle 1 = \int_{0}^{1} \frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}} = \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q}\frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}}$

Let $\displaystyle u = 1-x$ so that $\displaystyle du = -dx$,
$\displaystyle u(0) = 1$, $\displaystyle u(q) = 1-q$ and substituting
gives

\begin{align*}
1 &= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{cx}{\sqrt{1-x}} \\
&= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1-q}\frac{-c(1-u)}{\sqrt{u}} \\
&= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} c\int_{1-q}^{1}(\sqrt{u}^{-1}-\sqrt{u})\,du \\
&= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} c(2\sqrt{u} - \frac{2u^{3/2}}{3})\big|_{1-q}^{1} \\
&= \lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \big(c(2\sqrt{1} - \frac{2(1)^{3/2}}{3}) - c(2\sqrt{1-q} - \frac{2(1-q)^{3/2}}{3})\big)\\
&= c\left(2 - \frac{2}{3}\right)\\
&= \frac{4c}{3}
\end{align*}

and isolating for c gives us that $c = 3/4$.
hints:
The function itself gives a natural restriction on how big \emph{b} can
be. What goes wrong with your function if \emph{b} is too big?
The fact that a pdf is positive gives you a restriction on \emph{a}.

All pdfs have the property that the area under the curve where the
function is defined must be 1. Use this to find \emph{c}.
To integrate the function, use a substitution.
The substitution you seek is $\displaystyle u = 1-x$.
